Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Reciprocal Noticing: Latino/a Students and Teachers Constructing Common Resources in Mathematics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to extend the theoretical and methodological construct of noticing to develop the concept of reciprocal noticing, a process by which teacher and student noticing are shared. The researcher argues that through reciprocal noticing the classroom can become the space for more equitable mathematics learning, particularly for language learners. Thus, the focus of the project is on developing the concept of reciprocal noticing as a way to support better interactions between teachers and Latino/a students in elementary mathematics classrooms.

The project uses a transformative teaching experiment methodology and is guided by the initial conjectures that to make mathematics classrooms intellectually attractive places, Latino/a students and teachers need to learn to develop common resources for teaching and learning mathematics, and that reciprocal noticing as a process supports teachers and students in developing these common resources for teaching and learning mathematics. The project design centers around two research questions:How do teachers and Latino/a students tune to each other's mathematical ideas and explicitly indicate to one another how their ideas are important for discourse that promotes mathematical reasoning in classrooms characterized by reciprocal noticing? What patterns emerge across four classrooms when teachers and Latino/a students engage in reciprocal noticing?

The concept of reciprocal noticing can significantly enhance emerging research in mathematics education about the importance of teacher noticing. Further, this revised concept of noticing can transform mathematics classroom to better support English Language Learners.

The PI will incorporate project findings and videos into methods courses for preservice elementary teachers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project “Reciprocal Noticing: Latino/a Students and Teachers Constructing Common Resources in Mathematics,” has generated outcomes with important broader impacts for project participants, the field of mathematics education research and practice, and the society in general. First, participating teachers and students have benefited directly by learning to understand teaching and learning as a relational practice. The project was conducted in four classrooms, two in Texas and two in Michigan, with high concentrations of diverse students and limited material and economic resources. The teachers and students in these classrooms learned to reciprocate each other’s ways of thinking about mathematical concepts and, as a result were able to construct the kind of common resources for teaching and learning that no educational policy, economic circumstance, or curricular change can take away because these resources are intellectual, collective, and generative. 

Second, the project has impacted the development of mathematics education research and practice by contributing a theorization of reciprocal noticing that recognizes the interactive and relational nature of noticing. This recognition adds visibility to language and culture in diverse classrooms where students engage multimodalities such as sounds, gestures, or drawings, for noticing important dimensions of mathematical concepts. These multimodalities extend the conceptualization of noticing from its original cognitive base to a relational and socially organized phenomenon. Based on this reconceptualization of noticing, the project has generated a number of research and practice papers, including “Theorizing Reciprocal Noticing with Non-dominant Students in Mathematics,” (Educational Studies in Mathematics), “Mirrors and Windows into Student Noticing” (Teaching Children Mathematics) and a book chapter “Learning to Think Differently: Rerouting the Whole Mathematics Trip” (Access and Equity: Promoting High Quality Mathematics in Grades 3-5. NCTM). These publications include methodologies, analytic approaches, and powerful examples intended to advance both research and practice toward more holistic, dynamic, and humane ways of understanding the complexly beautiful work of teachers and students in diverse classrooms. In 2015, the PI received the Linking Research and Practice Outstanding Publication Award, which reflects this important outcome of the project regarding creative ways of connecting research and practice in mathematics education in diverse classrooms. 

            Finally, the impact on society consists of bringing teachers of non-dominant students (in our country and abroad) to recognize difference as a resource instead of as a deficit to be fixed. Given the increasingly diverse classrooms in our country, and the immigration movements around the world, bringing teachers closer to students’ life experiences is not a small impact on education. Nationally, this project has impacted classrooms with African American, Latinos/as, English learners, and recent immigrant students. At an international level, the project attracted attention from scholars in Chile and Mexico. Capitalizing on the emerging findings from this project, the PI developed a community outreach project that created a teaching/research exchange between participating teachers in this CAREER project and an elementary school in Santiago, Chile. In the case of Mexico, the PI was motivated by the project’s findings to submit a Fulbright proposal to continue working with teachers in this country in order to continue exploring the construct of reciprocal noticing in international contexts.
